articles.headline: U.S. Debated Cyberwarfare in Attack Plan on Libya
articles.snippet: Obama administration officials decided to use airstrikes to disrupt and disable the Qaddafi government in March, but only after a new kind of warfare was discussed.
articles.abstract: Obama administration officials decided to use airstrikes to disrupt and disable the Qaddafi government in March, but only after a new kind of warfare was discussed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just before the American-led strikes against Libya in March, the Obama administration intensely debated whether to open the mission with a new kind of warfare: a cyberoffensive to disrupt and even disable the Qaddafi government’s air-defense system, which threatened allied warplanes.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Farmers Facing Loss of Subsidy May Get New One
articles.snippet: Farming is a very healthy business, spurring calls to end its large government safety net. But some lawmakers want to create a new program instead.
articles.abstract: Farming is a very healthy business, spurring calls to end its large government safety net. But some lawmakers want to create a new program instead.
articles.lead_paragraph: It seems a rare act of civic sacrifice: in the name of deficit reduction, lawmakers from both parties are calling for the end of a longstanding agricultural subsidy that puts about $5 billion a year in the pockets of their farmer constituents. Even major farm groups are accepting the move, saying that with farmers poised to reap bumper profits, they must do their part.

articles.headline: Massachusetts Tries to Rein In Its Health Costs
articles.snippet: After passing a landmark health bill, Massachusetts is now looking to become the first state to radically change the way health care providers are paid.
articles.abstract: After passing a landmark health bill, Massachusetts is now looking to become the first state to radically change the way health care providers are paid.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — On the Republican campaign trail, the health care debate has focused on the mandatory coverage that Mitt Romney signed into law as governor in 2006. But back in Massachusetts the conversation has moved on, and lawmakers are now confronting the problem that Mr. Romney left unaddressed: the state’s spiraling health care costs.
articles.byline: By Abby Goodnough and Kevin Sack

articles.headline: Accounting Board Criticizes Deloitte’s Auditing System
articles.snippet: In an unprecedented rebuke to a major accounting firm, the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board said Deloitte & Touche lacked adequate quality control.
articles.abstract: In an unprecedented rebuke to a major accounting firm, the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board said Deloitte & Touche lacked adequate quality control.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an unprecedented rebuke to a major accounting firm, the group that oversees the industry released a report criticizing Deloitte & Touche, saying that it lacked an adequate system of quality control in its audits.

articles.headline: Warming Revives Dream of Sea Route in Russian Arctic
articles.snippet: As global warming melts the polar ice sheet, shipping, fishing and mining interests are looking to take advantage of the newly accessible Arctic Ocean.
articles.abstract: As global warming melts the polar ice sheet, shipping, fishing and mining interests are looking to take advantage of the newly accessible Arctic Ocean.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARKHANGELSK, Russia — Rounding the northernmost tip of Russia in his oceangoing tugboat this summer, Capt. Vladimir V. Bozanov saw plenty of walruses, some pods of beluga whales and in the distance a few icebergs.

articles.headline: Countless Grievances, One Thread: We’re Angry
articles.snippet: The Occupy protests across the country are marked by each city’s stew of circumstances and grievances, but the protesters seem united in feeling that the system is stacked against them.
articles.abstract: The Occupy protests across the country are marked by each city’s stew of circumstances and grievances, but the protesters seem united in feeling that the system is stacked against them.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Ken Alandt’s guitar, which he covered with bumper stickers and waved in the air at the Occupy Phoenix protest on Monday, is a symbol of the movement itself — a mélange of disparate causes, all of which prompt his blood to boil.

articles.headline: For Wealthy Indian Family, Palatial House Is Not a Home
articles.snippet: An extravagant 27-story house built in Mumbai by India’s richest man, Mukesh Ambani, has been completed, but the owners apparently have not moved in — raising questions as to why.
articles.abstract: An extravagant 27-story house built in Mumbai by India’s richest man, Mukesh Ambani, has been completed, but the owners apparently have not moved in — raising questions as to why.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — When India’s richest man completed his extravagant 27-story new house here last year, it incited a public debate along the lines of “What’s he trying to prove?”

articles.headline: Hopes of Big Deal in Europe, Then Denials
articles.snippet: France may be placed on watch for a downgrade if the costs of supporting banks and other euro countries hurt its finances, the agency said.
articles.abstract: France may be placed on watch for a downgrade if the costs of supporting banks and other euro countries hurt its finances, the agency said.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The roller-coaster saga of Europe’s debt crisis continued Tuesday, as hopes that Germany and France were near agreement on a big infusion of bailout money sent American stocks up in late trading.
